title.narrative: DEMAND FOR IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS ON CHILD FEEDING AND CARE PRACTICES

description.narrative: By 2020, women and caregivers are equipped with the knowledge and skills for improved child feeding and care practices, which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Child Health, Early Childhood Development, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition (Covid), Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Children and women in vulnerable regions demand and use high-quality and proven preventive and curative nutrition interventions, including in emergency situations.

Diet diversity in early childhood (children under 5), includes complementary feeding and MNPs

Technical assistance - Prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2020, women and caregivers are equipped with the knowledge and skills for improved child feeding and care practices

description.narrative: Community-based approach enabled to empower communities and families and increase their knowledge and skills on IYCF. Key messages on Infant and Young Child Feeding (IYCF) in the context of Covid-19 have been disseminated in French and English. Community platforms set-up enabled to transmit messages to 143,567 persons. In total 56,311 parents of children aged 0 to 5 years sensitized on measures to prevent spread of COVID-19. Additionally, 1,167 CHWs were trained and equipped to influence their peers in IYCF and 527 trained on preventive measures related to COVID-19. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:30/06/2020

In humanitarian situations: Number of service delivery points (health facility or community) that provide IYCF counselling
